description: From Middle English abroche, from Norman, from Old French abroche (“to spigot”). Equivalent to a- +‎ broach.

entries.meaning: Tapped; broached. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
Astir; moving about. [First attested in the early 16th century.]
(obsolete) Broached; in a condition for letting out or yielding liquor, as a cask which is tapped. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470).]
examples: Jupiter, in the beginning of his reign, finding the world much more innocent than it is in this iron age, poured very plentifully out of the tun that stood at his right hand; but as mankind degenerated, and became unworthy of his blessings, he set abroach the other vessel, that filled the world with pain and poverty  […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In a state to be diffused or propagated. [First attested in the early 16th century.]

verbs.description: abroach (third-person singular simple present abroaches, present participle abroaching, simple past and past participle abroached)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To set abroach; to let out, as liquor; to broach; to tap.
examples: on the crosse a pike / Did set again abroach
